f5c95cc981bd.name: Startup Grind
f5c95cc981bd.shortDescription: The life, work, and tactics of entrepreneurs around the…

paragraphs.text: 1. Write every day.
paragraphs.name: 2d0a
dac1
paragraphs.text: The inverse of finding your tribe is this: don’t try to write for them. Writing for a whole group of people is crazy-making. Writing and reading are too subjective for that. So pick a person — just one — and write for them.

paragraphs.name: 6dd5
paragraphs.text: I take a book to the bathroom with me and I have episodes of foreign language and english films on my phone constantly. Does this count?
1. Write every day.
paragraphs.name: 2d0a

paragraphs.text: A movie is a way to get an entire story in two hours. And writers should be story junkies. Pay attention to the structure of a movie, how its paced, which parts work for you and which don’t.
paragraphs.name: 286a
286a
paragraphs.text: A movie is a way to get an entire story in two hours. And writers should be story junkies. Pay attention to the structure of a movie, how its paced, which parts work for you and which don’t.
Plan on spending about $1500 and start saving your pennies. The hope is that your first book will pay for your second.

paragraphs.name: 86a7
paragraphs.text: I’m going to end in the same place. None of the rest of the suggestions here can replace a daily writing habit. Write everyday and finish your manuscripts.
Thank you!
paragraphs.name: 97ed

51b4352649e8.title: Well… it might end up being something like your 5th book paying for your first four.

paragraphs.text: Well… it might end up being something like your 5th book paying for your first four. Books are long-term investments. Break a few eggs to make an omelette kind of things. :D

paragraphs.text: Really great advice! Thank you! I especially appreciate #7 — I find that nothing dries up the creative tap worse than writing to please a crowd, but with an audience of one, that’s when the truly weird and wonderful emerges. It seems like writers can get stage fright, after all.
